movies.description: Louisa “Lou” Clark (Emilia Clarke), an unstable and creative girl, lives in a small village in the English countryside. She lives aimlessly, moving from one job to another to help her family make ends meet. However, a new job will test her usual joy. At the local castle, she takes care of and accompanies Will Traynor (Sam Claflin), a young and wealthy banker who became paralyzed after an accident.

locationCreated.description: The protagonists travel to the beach to cheer up Will and teach Louisa to let go a little and embrace adventure.

image.description: Scene from the movie Before You, aerial view of the hotel
Scene from the movie Before You on the beach at night, with Will and Louisa
Garden of the Barceló hotel in Pollensa from the movie, showing a chillout area with lots of vegetation and traditional Mallorcan structures
Pollensa beach, where the scene from the movie Before You was filmed

locationCreated.name: Hotel Barceló Playa de Pollensa

movies.name: Before You

review.reviewBody:
**Changing one's fixed mindset is not an easy task.**

Based on the novel of the same name, directed by a new filmmaker. This British movie stars two young sensations, Sam Claflin and Emilia Clarke, in the lead roles. It tells the story of a young man who has recently been paralyzed and meets his new caregiver. At first, neither of them fits with the other, but over time, things change as they engage in some outdoor activities together. As the movie progresses, it becomes more and more emotional. Also, it's fun to watch the first two acts, especially the performances of both protagonists, which make a strong impact.

After a long time, I watched a good emotional drama, but not too intense. It's a simple story, with no big adventures or romances. Yes, it's not a romantic movie, and if you go into it expecting one, you'll definitely be disappointed. It also conveys a somewhat negative message about being seriously ill and still alive. This theme only touches on humanity, but in the end, everyone has the right to do whatever they want because it's their life.

That said, the film avoids usual clichés. There are no scenes you’ve seen in other films with similar themes. This was deliberately avoided to make it a fresh piece. Basically, if you look closely, both main characters have different agendas about their lives. In particular, the caregiver never seriously attempted to fulfill her task.

On the other hand, those parts were very realistic, but still give us a cinematic experience thanks to the elegant screen presentation. It's definitely a good movie, I think everyone should watch it, because there are no drugs, sex, nudity, or intense kissing scenes. The main theme is a bit disturbing, especially for people with a sensitive heart. Apart from that, I hope you watch it if you haven’t already.

_7/10_

image.description: Poster of the movie A Long Way Down
image.name: Poster

image.description: Background image of the movie A Long Way Down
image.name: Backdrop

movies.description: Four lost souls—a disgraced TV presenter, a foul-mouthed teen, an isolated single mother, and a solipsistic muso—decide to end their lives on the same night, New Year's Eve. When this disillusioned quartet of strangers meet unintentionally at the same suicide hotspot, a London high-rise with the well-earned nickname Topper's Tower, they mutually agree to call off their plans for six weeks, forming an unconventional, dysfunctional family. They become media sensations as the Topper House Four and search together for the reasons to keep on living.

locationCreated.description: The characters visit Camp de Mar as a moment of escape and connection, offering a peaceful break from their struggles and a chance to bond outside the chaos of their everyday lives.

image.description: Scene from the movie A Long Way Down, showing the iconical bridge in Camp de Mar
Camp de Mar's beach bridge to the restaurant, where the scene from the movie A Long Way Down was filmed

locationCreated.name: Camp de Mar

movies.name: A Long Way Down

review.reviewBody:
A dark comedy movie from the Britain which was partially based on a novel of the same name. The second movie together for the rising stars Imogen Poots and Aaron Paul after 'Need for Speed'. The trailer was one of the reasons I watch this movie. It created an interest in me for some uniqueness in its theme. But in the end when I watched the movie now it did not last much longer.

Usually movies will have best shots for last parts, but here it came very early. The opening scene was the movie's highlight, get off with the fun and then while advancement it slowly died. The concept was really a good one, the story created around it was not. I expected twists and turns in last parts that never came. So, in the end it became a simple and the usual entertaining movie.

All the actors were good, but their characters were not convinced enough. The developments were to blame because all the four main characters were not exposed well on the screen about some of the mysteries of their earlier stages. I mean the story talks about each of them's difficulties they recently went through and 50% of them remained unexplained phenomena. Like, what was the Aaron Paul's real problems and about Imogen Poots little sister etc.

Beside all these flaws, there's little enjoyments. Toni Collette and Pierce Brosnan's roles were made sense and blended well with the concept. But when it comes to performances all the four were equally good. Overall, a fine subject was wasted for not that good story. Yes, a little let down movie, should have been a better. I don't know the book, maybe they should have adapted it straight without changing much. A decent movie to watch and no guarantee of satisfactory because differ from people to people.

6.5/10
